verses.text: After Abimelech, Tola son of Puah, son of Dodo, a man of Issachar, arose to rescue Israel. He lived in Shamir, in the hill country of Ephraim.
verses.comment: Tola's role as deliverer echoes the recurring theme of God raising up judges to save His people. The mention of his tribe and residence roots him among Israel's leaders, highlighting God's use of ordinary men.

verses.text: He judged Israel for twenty-three years; then he died and was buried at Shamir.
verses.comment: The lengthy rule of Tola suggests a period of relative peace. His burial at Shamir may indicate his importance in Ephraim, a center of worship in later periods.

verses.text: After him arose Jair the Gileadite, who judged Israel for twenty-two years.
verses.comment: Jair's Gileadite heritage points to God's work through different tribes. Like Tola, he serves as a judge for many years, showing Israel's continued need for guidance.

verses.text: He had thirty sons who rode on thirty donkeys. They had thirty towns in Gilead, which are called Havvoth-jair to this day.
verses.comment: The thirty sons ruling thirty towns hints at a dynastic influence and stability. The use of donkeys shows wealth and peaceful rule, contrasting with times of war.

verses.text: Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
verses.comment: Jair’s burial in Kamon marks an end of another era of leadership and peace. His burial location is preserved, suggesting respect for godly rulers.

verses.text: Once again, the people of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD, serving the Baals and the Ashtaroth, and the gods of Aram, Sidon, Moab, Ammon, and the Philistines. They abandoned the LORD and did not serve Him.
verses.comment: Here begins a familiar pattern—Israel falls into idolatry by worshiping foreign gods. Their apostasy reveals spiritual consequences when unity and faithfulness are forgotten.

verses.text: The anger of the LORD burned against Israel, so He gave them over to the Philistines and the Ammonites.
verses.comment: God’s wrath and discipline are described almost as a natural consequence of their rebellion, reminding us of the justice that follows turning from God.

verses.text: That year, they crushed and oppressed the Israelites for eighteen years—all the Israelites who lived beyond the Jordan in Gilead, the land of the Amorites.
verses.comment: The suffering is intense and lasting for nearly a generation, indicating how deep the consequences of turning from God can run within a community.

verses.text: The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin, and Ephraim, and Israel was in great distress.
verses.comment: Oppression now spreads to the heartland, escalating Israel’s crisis. Their distress points to spiritual as well as physical consequences.

verses.text: Then the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, saying, 'We have sinned against You, because we have abandoned our God and served the Baals.'
verses.comment: Israel’s confession is a return to God, reminiscent of repentance before receiving grace. Their admission echoes later prayers of repentance and patterns of renewal.

verses.text: The LORD replied to the Israelites: 'Did I not deliver you from Egypt, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,'
verses.comment: God recalls His saving acts, emphasizing His faithfulness and reminding the people of His constant readiness to deliver. This mirrors God’s saving acts throughout salvation history.

verses.text: 'And when the Sidonians, Amalekites, and Maonites oppressed you, you cried out to Me, and I rescued you from their hands.'
verses.comment: God lists various deliverances, showing His mercy across generations. This reminds believers that divine rescue is available when genuine repentance occurs.

verses.text: 'Yet you have forsaken Me and served other gods; therefore, I will save you no more.'
verses.comment: This is a strong warning from God, reflecting the consequence of persistent sin. The tension points to salvation depending both on God's mercy and on our free response.

verses.text: 'Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen; let them save you in your time of distress.'
verses.comment: God’s challenge exposes the emptiness of idolatry and calls for exclusive worship. This passage emphasizes the futility of placing hope in anything but God.

verses.text: And the Israelites said to the LORD, 'We have sinned; do to us whatever seems good to You. Only please rescue us this day.'
verses.comment: Their humble plea demonstrates true repentance—a model for believers seeking mercy. This submission to God’s will is the heart of spiritual renewal.

verses.text: So they removed the foreign gods from among them and served the LORD, and He could no longer bear Israel's suffering.
verses.comment: Their actions match their confession, fulfilling the call to true conversion. God’s compassion is stirred—a precursor to later teachings on divine mercy and forgiveness.

verses.text: Then the Ammonites were called together and camped in Gilead, and the Israelites assembled and camped at Mizpah.
verses.comment: This military gathering sets the stage for God’s next deliverance. Mizpah would become a significant place for Israel’s unity and spiritual assembly.

verses.text: The people and the leaders of Gilead said to one another, 'Who will be the man to begin the fight against the Ammonites? He shall be the head of all the inhabitants of Gilead.'
verses.comment: The desire for a leader foreshadows the coming of a savior-figure, ultimately fulfilled perfectly in Christ as head and mediator (see Rom. 5:10-11). The role of single leadership in salvation history points ultimately to the unity of God’s people under a divinely appointed and singular head.
